summary:
I'm an Electronic and Micro-fabrication Engineer with 5+ years' experience in micro-size gas and pH sensors and transistor and PCB level mixed-signal electronics.

I'm passionate about contributing and innovating in science and engineering for companies, people's health and security, and I've spent the last 5 years using my expertise in electronics, microfabrication, and applied physics.

I've published papers in scientific journals and international conferences for my research in graphene-based gas and pH sensors during my PhD. 
I've won the Graduate Teaching Assistant of the year 2017 in the Faculty of Engineering in Imperial College London for the excellence in teaching during my PhD.
I've been awarded the Nicolas Battersby prize by Imperial College London for my excellence in Analogue Electronics during my undergraduate degree in Electrical and Electronic Engineering.

I'm currently seeking full time and remote jobs in mixed-signal electronics design, so if you'd like to work together, contact me by LinkedIn message.

currentPositions.description: Developing point-of-care electronic sensing system for real-time breath monitoring to enable early detection of sepsis and prevent their development to septic shock.
currentPositions.title: Marie Sklodowska Curie Research Fellow

headquarters.line1: University House "Anastasios G. Leventis"​ 1 University Avenue, 2109

projects.description: The main goal of this project is the development of a realistic model for the interface of an ISFET (Ion Sensitive Field Effect Transistor) with an electrolyte and simulate its operation as function of the electrolyte pH. This approach is different from equivalent circuit approaches in the sense that the electrolyte-ISFET gate surface interactions are taken into account. This model will be useful for the design of future ISFET structures. The industry standard simulation package “Sentaurus” TCAD (Technology Coputer Aided Design) from “Synopsys Inc.” was used for semiconductor device simulations and “COMSOL Multiphysics” by “COMSOL Inc.” was used for the simulation of the Electrical Double Layer (EDL) formation in the electrolyte.
projects.title: A Complete ISFET - Electrolyte Interface Model and Simulation

projects.description: Work in the Smart Energy laboratory of EEE Department in Imperial College London under the Control and Power research group. Research about the advantages of wide band gap semiconductors in power applications and Gallium Nitride devices. Change the design of the cells of a lab scale Alternate Arm Converter used in HVDC applications.
projects.title: UROP: Optimise the efficiency of the Alternate Arm Converter using Gallium Nitride devices

publications.name: Through-Graphene Etching of Porous Silicon via Electroless Metal Assisted Chemical Etching
publications.description:
We investigated two strategies for fabricating Si Nanowire Arrays (NWA) covered with Graphene. The first was to etch Si NWAs by Metal Assisted Chemical Etching (MACE) on substrates with pre-transferred Graphene. The second was to transfer Graphene on pre-etched Si NWAs.

Conclusions:
• SiO2 can be etched through graphene via HF vapour without degrading the electrical conductivity of graphene.
• Ag nucleation on graphene is significantly larger than on Si due to defects caused by the chemicals in the process and
increases with increasing AgNO3 volume in the solution.
• Graphene acts as a mask for MACE NW etching at low AgNO3 volume in the solution.
• Graphene-last on NWA creates a much improved contact on Si NWA than a Cu pressure contact.

Ammonia (NH3) is a toxic gas released in different industrial, agricultural and natural processes. It is also a biomarker for some diseases. These require NH3 sensors for health and safety reasons. To boost the sensitivity of solid-state sensors, the effective sensing area should be increased. Two methods are explored and compared using an evaporating pool of 0.5 mL NH4OH (28% NH3). In the first method an array of Si nanowires (Si NWA) is obtained via metal-assisted-electrochemical etching to increase the effective surface area. In the second method CVD graphene is suspended on top of the Si nanowires to act as a sensing layer. Both the effective surface area as well as the density of surface traps influences the amplitude of the response. The effective surface area of Si NWAs is 100 × larger than that of suspended graphene for the same top surface area, leading to a larger response in amplitude by a factor of ~7 notwithstanding a higher trap density in suspended graphene. The use of Si NWAs increases the response rate for both Si NWAs as well as the suspended graphene due to more effective NH3 diffusion processes.
publications.name: Ammonia Sensing using Arrays of Silicon Nanowires and Graphene

publications.description: In this paper, we report a method to improve sensitivity for CMOS ISFET arrays using Reactive Ion Etching (RIE) as a post-processing technique. The process etches away the passivation layers of the commercial CMOS process, using an oxygen (O 2 ) and sulfur hexafluoride (SF 6 ) plasma. The resulting attenuation and pH sensitivity are characterised for five dies etched for 0 to 15 minutes, and we demonstrate that capacitive attenuation is reduced by 196% and pH sensitivity increased by 260% compared to the non-etched equivalent. The spread of trapped charge is also reduced which relaxes requirements on the analogue front-end. The technique significantly improves the performance of the fully-integrated sensing system for applications such as DNA detection.
publications.name: Improving the pH Sensitivity of ISFET Arrays with Reactive Ion Etching
Graphene Suspended on Silicon Nanowire Arrays for Enhanced Gas Sensing
publications.publisher: IOP 231st Electro-Chemical Society Meeting, New Orleans US, 28 May - 1 June, 2017

publications.description:
• Successful one step RIE plasma etching for post-process CMOS ISFETs improvement.

• pH sensitivity - passivation capacitance increased by 125%–5700%, respectively.

• Capacitive attenuation is reduced by 96%
publications.name: Performance improvement of commercial ISFET sensors using reactive ion etching

publications.description:
• CMOS ISFETs passivation layers plasma etching method for minimal surface roughness.

• Identification of spatial distribution of trapped charge in CMOS ISFET passivation.

• Performance improvement of CMOS ISFETs including 731% increase in sensitivity.
publications.name: Mechanisms for enhancement of sensing performance in CMOS ISFET arrays using reactive ion etching
publications.publisher: Elsevier Sensors and Actuators B: Chemical

publications.name: Graphene on Si nanowire arrays as solvent vapour sensor
publications.description:
* Suspended graphene on Silicon Nanowire Arrays for centimetres of area

* Used this device to measure in real-time acetone IPA vapour

* The graphene-nanowire sensor can be used for exhaled VOCs as biomarkers for diseases such as diabetes, lung cancer and more.
publications.publisher: 9th International SiGe Technology and Device Meeting (ISTDM) 11th International Conference on Silicon Epitaxy and Heterostructures (ICSI)

publications.name: Optimising the performance of commercial ISFET sensors using Reactive Ion Etching
publications.description: Boost of pH sensitivity in commercial CMOS sensors by etching down the top layers of the fabricated chips using RIE. The etching recipe was calibrated to etch the polyimide layer while leaving the minimum required oxide thickness for sensing. Different etch times were applied on five dies which were characterised to extract pH sensitivity.

publications.name: Graphene coated CMOS ISFETs for pH sensing
publications.description: Using Polymer-Assisted Graphene Transfer (PAGT) process we coat CMOS ISFET arrays with graphene sheets and characterise them with Raman spectroscopy, interferometry and microscopy. Subsequently, we perform pH sensing, drift and noise experiments and analyse the results. We find that graphene coated ISFETs drift less and slower than the uncoated devices. This, is the first step of proving the potential of minimising the drawbacks of the CMOS ISFETs using 2D materials that will enable more reliable pH sensing devices.
publications.publisher: European Graphene Forum, Lisbon Portugal, 23-25 October 2019

ingestedContentSummary.description: In 1908, the English philosopher J. M. E. McTaggart published an important paper on the logic of time.
ingestedContentSummary.title: How logic alone may prove that time doesn’t exist

message.text:
Interesting article about time! 
I always appreciate fundamental physics and how it affects our lives. Einstein’s theory of relativity is essential for modern computers and the internet. Without it clocks on satellites wouldn’t be synchronised correctly with ground ones. Hence, gps and so many more technologies wouldn’t work. 

This article suggests that time is an illusion. Interesting new perspective. Let’s see if this theory will be proven to be real and more interestingly how it will affect our lives!
